podcasts.title: Coldplay Scandal: Astronomer CEO caught in an Affair with Head of HR - A Corporate Crisis Playbook
podcasts.description:
This isn't our usual deep dive into scaling businesses, but the recent 'Coldplay affair reveal' involving the Astronomer CEO and his Head of HR caught on camera cheating offers some brutal, real-world lessons for any leader. What started as a viral TikTok moment from a Coldplay session quickly blew up into a full-blown corporate crisis, shaking a company that had just closed a significant funding round.

We break down what happened, how a seemingly private incident became a global spectacle, and the very public fallout. Manuel and I discuss the company's response – from their initial statements to the CEO's resignation, and whether they handled it swiftly and effectively. 

We explore the incredibly thin line between personal conduct and corporate responsibility, especially when you're at the top. When does a private affair become a company's problem? And what does it say about your culture when your leadership is involved in something like this?

This episode isn't about gossip; it's about the hard realities of modern crisis communication, the power dynamics within an organization, and the true cost of a misstep in the public eye. We share our take on how a company navigates such a storm and what it takes for leaders, even those who've made significant errors, to bounce back.

What's your take on how companies should handle these kinds of public personal crises?

Chapters
- 00:00 Intro: Corporate Life, Personal Affairs
- 00:49 The Astronomer Affair: A Quick Rundown
- 03:23 Company's Official Response & Timeline
- 06:12 Why Did This Go So Viral?
- 09:58 Handling Crisis: Fast, Factual, Human
- 13:57 Personal vs. Corporate: Where's the Line?
- 18:06 Power Dynamics & Conflict of Interest
- 28:32 Firing Both or Just the CEO?
- 35:56 The Co-Founder's Role in Recovery
- 42:47 Bouncing Back from Public Scrutiny

If you found this discussion valuable, hit subscribe for more raw, unvarnished insights into building and scaling businesses. Visit my website for more resources and connect with us on social media!

podcasts.title: Building in Silence & Authenticity in the Age of AI | Unfiltered Entrepreneurship 5
podcasts.description:
In this provocative episode of Scaling the Unscalable, Manuel and I challenge the "build in public" gospel. 

Is it always the right move? 

We explore my philosophy of "building in silence" – the crucial period of laying your foundations and building your bones before you start talking. We then dissect the "fake it till you make it" mantra, distinguishing between healthy projection that fuels your vision and the harmful, substance-less pretending that plagues social media.

How do you prove you're human in a world flooded with AI? We share a radical idea: intentionally adding spelling errors to your content. 
This conversation navigates the new frontier of authenticity, from rejecting generic AI scripts to tackling the dark side of engagement. We explore the psychology of online hate with the powerful idea that "hate only comes from below," and share a cautionary tale of a massive influencer who rage-quit LinkedIn after his vanity metrics crashed.

This isn't just about posting – it's about strategy. Join us as we reveal why moving to video, owning your audience off-platform, and focusing on quantity and consistency are the only true levers for success in a world where you can't predict virality.

Chapters:
00:06 - Introduction: Social Media for Entrepreneurs
00:20 - The "Build Your Bones" Philosophy: Silence vs. Public
01:24 - Fake It Till You Make It: Healthy Projection vs. Harmful Pretending
04:02 - The Power of Feedback When Building in Public
05:00 - The Danger of Scaling Too Soon: Why You'll Crash and Burn
08:05 - Using Public Sharing as a "Public Journal"
09:36 - The Real Goal: Go-to-Market Strategy & Product-Market Fit
10:30 - My 5-Year Rule: Why I Didn't Give Advice Early On
11:47 - The Problem with Giving Advice (And a Better Way to Share)
14:56 - My Organic Journey to 35K+ LinkedIn Followers
17:35 - The Dangers of Vanity Metrics & The Love-Hate Relationship with Social Media
18:38 - Using Social Media as a Machine, Not for Self-Validation
19:18 - Why I Don't Use AI for My Content
20:30 - The Generic Feel of AI-Generated Posts
22:20 - How to Prove You're Human (The Spelling Error Trick)
25:44 - Handling Haters: The Psychology of Negative Comments
33:46 - Is Social Media Breaking Real Communication?
39:00 - The Strategy of Unfollowing Everyone for a Cleaner Feed
42:15 - The Psychology of Haters: "Hate Only Comes From Below"
43:20 - Navigating Cancel Culture & The Court of Public Opinion
48:50 - Mindless Scrolling vs. Intentional Learning
50:50 - The Counter-Movement: Why Long-Form Content is Winning
55:17 - The Future of Your Personal Brand
56:10 - The 3 Questions: Defining Your Audience, Topics, & Message
57:37 - The Cautionary Tale of the Rage-Quitting Influencer
1:00:02 - Platform Dependency: You Don't Own Your Audience
1:01:44 - Why We're Moving to Video and Owning Our Data
1:04:44 - The Real Secret to Going Viral: Quantity & Consistency

podcasts.title: Mika Tikkala on Growth & Communities | Scaling the Unscalable 4
podcasts.description:
This week on Scaling the Unscalable, I sat down with Mika Tikkala, a seasoned entrepreneur with 16 years of hard-won experience in driving growth. From organizing large-scale marketing events to building hundreds of sales teams and hiring over a thousand salespeople, Mika has seen it all. Our conversation got real about the practical, often unglamorous, aspects of scaling a business and keeping customers for the long haul.

We kicked things off by dissecting customer success – what it truly means beyond the buzzwords. Mika lays out the three critical elements: validated value, consistent excitement, and unwavering trust. We explored the tricky balance of delivering enough value without spoiling customers, and why relying solely on automated surveys for feedback is a mistake that stifles genuine connection. My view? Sometimes, you need to do the unscalable thing: have real, messy conversations early on to understand what your customers *actually* value.

Then we dove into building sales teams, a challenge I'm personally navigating with Division 5 right now. Mika shared his pragmatic 5-step framework, starting with the absolute necessity of documenting your entire sales process. We also tackled the uncomfortable truth about ego in leadership, the difference between entrepreneurs, leaders, and managers, and why acknowledging effort—not just results—is crucial for team growth.

Mika also shared insights from building his "Customer Retention Mastery" community, a direct response to the overpriced consultants and social media gurus. We discussed the power of co-creation in smaller communities versus the noise and top-down control of larger ones. Finally, we reflected on our love-hate relationship with social media for personal branding and business growth, including Mika's shocking experience of losing 12,000 LinkedIn followers overnight.

It was a raw, honest discussion about the realities of building and scaling, often through unscalable efforts. We covered everything from direct customer feedback to the dangers of ego and the essential truth that good relationships, not algorithms, drive sustainable growth.

How have you balanced the need for quick profits with building lasting customer relationships? Let me know in the comments.

Chapters:
- 00:00 - Intro & Guest Introduction
- 00:39 - Mika's 16 Years in Entrepreneurship: Growth, Events, Sales, Customer Success
- 03:10 - Events in the Post-Pandemic & AI Era
- 05:56 - The Core of Customer Success: Value, Excitement, Trust
- 07:56 - The Tricky Balance of Providing Value
- 10:26 - Human Touch vs. Automation in Customer Feedback
- 14:44 - Building a Rebellious Community: Customer Retention Mastery
- 19:40 - The Challenge of Scaling Communities Authentically
- 24:34 - Building and Scaling Sales Teams: Mika's 5 Steps
- 28:35 - The Reality of Ego-Free Leadership
- 35:40 - The Entrepreneur, Leader, and Manager Dynamic
- 38:33 - The Love-Hate Relationship with Social Media for Founders
- 43:29 - The Dark Side of Social Media Algorithms
- 46:15 - What's Next for Mika

If you found value in this conversation, hit that subscribe button, leave a comment, and share it with a fellow founder who needs to hear these truths.

Share your thoughts in the comments below, and let's keep the conversation going.

podcasts.title: Valon Asani: Building the Albanian love platform with @dua_com | Scaling the Unscalable 3​
podcasts.description:
Starting a business is one thing; scaling it is another entirely. My guest, Valon Asani, embodies the brutal realities of entrepreneurship, from starting with just $3,000 and running out of cash, to building two businesses while working a full-time job. He’s seen it all, including the infamous "shiny object syndrome" that plagues so many founders.

In this candid conversation, Valon shares his journey from diversifying into countless ventures – from pellet factories to dental clinics – to the pivotal moment he realized the critical need for extreme focus. We delve deep into the story of Dua.com, a dating app launched during the pandemic that defied all odds, not just by scaling to over a million users but by doing so with a zero-marketing budget. It’s a powerful testament to product-led growth and prioritizing quality above all else.

We also tackle the eternal debate: product versus service. Valon explains why he believes product is the "Champions League" of scaling, while also acknowledging the unique challenges of building something truly "remarkable" in a crowded market. More than just a dating app, Dua.com has become a mission-driven platform focused on preserving Albanian heritage and connecting a global diaspora.

This episode is packed with hard-won lessons on resilience, the importance of saying "no" to distractions, learning from negative feedback, and fostering collaboration in a culture that often struggles with it.

What’s your experience with the "shiny object syndrome" in your own business? Have you ever had to cut everything to truly focus?

Chapters:
- 00:20 Valon's Entrepreneurial Start
- 01:44 The "Side Hustle" That Built an Empire
- 03:05 Driving Factor: The Entrepreneurial Blood
- 04:48 Solo Grind to Partnered Success
- 06:33 The "Shiny Object Syndrome" Trap
- 08:35 Why We Had to "Cut Everything"
- 08:57 Launching Dua.com in a Pandemic
- 11:54 The Danger of Going Wide
- 14:03 Six Years to Understand One Business
- 15:21 Product vs. Service: The Scaling Debate
- 16:48 Why Product Beats Service (Usually)
- 21:14 Quality Over Sales: Dua's Zero Marketing Growth
- 28:58 The Unlikely Origin of Dua.com
- 31:28 Validation: The "Get in the Ring" Moment
- 33:40 Why "Good Enough" Isn't Enough for Your Product
- 35:26 Dua's Impact: 100,000+ Couples & Beyond
- 38:56 Preserving Albanian DNA: Dua's Mission
- 40:32 The Albanian "Warrior DNA" in Action
- 43:04 Kosovo vs. Albania: Collaboration Challenges
- 45:47 The Power of Giving Without Expectation
- 49:59 How Dua.com Makes Money
- 53:06 The Controversial Internationalization Pivot
- 59:49 The Future of Dua: Deep Focus & AI
- 1:03:09 The Hardest Skill: Saying "No"

podcasts.title: What is happening with the Events space? | Unfiltered Entrepreneurship #4
podcasts.description:
The world of events has undergone a seismic shift, but not in the way many predicted. We thought digital was the future, especially after the pandemic. Turns out, the reality is far more interesting.

In this episode of Scaling the Unscalable, I sit down with my partner in business, Manuel, an events veteran with over 15 years of hard-won experience. Manuel, the mind behind iconic events like Pirate Summit that put Cologne on the European startup map, shares how the space has evolved from corporate, business-card-swapping affairs to something truly experiential.

We dive into the unexpected post-pandemic shifts: why attendees commit later than ever, the crucial need for events to stand out, and the growing demand for deep, meaningful connections over superficial networking. But perhaps the most surprising insight is how the rise of AI is paradoxically pushing us back towards the physical world, making authentic human interaction more valuable than ever. We're talking realness over polish, and why imperfection is what truly defines us.

Manuel also shares pragmatic lessons for event organizers looking to succeed in 2025 and beyond: the power of storytelling, the importance of delivering on your promise, and why the "after-experience" dictates future attendance. Learn how AI can be a powerful tool for *organizing* events, but why it should often stay in the background when it comes to the *experience* itself.

Join us as we explore why, in an increasingly connected yet lonely world, in-person events are becoming indispensable for forging genuine human bonds.

Chapters:
- 00:00 - Introduction & Manuel's 15 years in events
- 01:08 - Event space before 2010: Corporate & boring
- 03:25 - Pirate Summit: Creating unique experiences
- 05:01 - Pandemic impact: Rise & fall of online events
- 07:59 - Post-pandemic attendee behavior: Late commitments
- 09:28 - The longing for real connection: Small gatherings
- 16:36 - Top 3 things for event success: Storytelling & promise
- 24:43 - AI's impact on in-person events: Why human connection wins
- 25:35 - Imperfection makes us human: The AI paradox
- 36:43 - Using AI *for* event organization, not *at* the event
- 43:32 - The future of Pirate Night: Community & entrepreneurship

If you found this episode valuable, make sure to like this video, subscribe to our channel for more no-nonsense insights into scaling businesses, and hit the notification bell so you don't miss our next episode. Visit our website for more resources and connect with us on social media!

podcasts.title: Fire Respectfully (But Quickly) | Unfiltered Entrepreneurship #3
podcasts.description:
Firing is one of the hardest, most dreaded tasks for any leader. But avoiding it often causes more damage. In this candid conversation from Scaling The Unscalable, Engjell and Manuel discuss how to handle terminations professionally, respectfully, and decisively.

Learn why delaying is the biggest mistake, and gain practical advice on:
📍 The importance of firing fast when the decision is made.
📍 Avoiding surprise terminations through clear prior communication.
📍 Using a "Yellow Card / Red Card" warning system.
📍 Leveraging the trial period effectively.
📍 Conducting the final conversation with clarity and humanity.
📍 Separating the person from the performance or fit issue.
📍 Parting ways respectfully and minimizing negative fallout.
📍 Providing support after termination (the "right thing to do").
📍 Mastering tough conversations by separating what needs to be said from how it's said.

Navigate this difficult process with more confidence and less collateral damage. Watch now.

Care to share your best tip for handling difficult conversations respectfully?

Chapters:
0:00:00 - Why you need to fire faster
0:03:00 - Yellow card before red card
0:06:00 - Clarity beats comfort in tough talks
0:09:00 - Fire with heart, not hesitation
0:12:00 - Firing shouldn’t burn bridges
0:15:00 - What happens *after* you fire someone?

podcasts.title: Performance Evaluations & Salary Increases | Unfiltered Entrepreneurship #2
podcasts.description:
How do you fairly evaluate performance, set salaries, and manage promotion expectations without demotivating your team? 

Engjell and Manuel tackle the sensitive topic of employee evaluation and compensation in this segment from Scaling The Unscalable.

Dive into practical strategies for:
📍 Setting initial salaries and the risks involved.
📍 Using performance-based bonuses effectively.
📍 Structuring productive review cycles.
📍 Handling salary increase requests fairly and sustainably.
📍 The pros and cons of salary transparency.
📍 Bridging the gap between manager assessment and employee self-perception.
📍 Defining clear success metrics (KPIs) for roles.
📍 Empowering employees by letting them help define their success.

Move beyond subjective feelings to create a clearer, fairer system for growth and compensation. Watch now!

💬 How do YOU define success for your team members? Comment below!

podcasts.title: How to Hire the Right People | Unfiltered Entrepreneurship #1
podcasts.description:
Hiring is more than just filling a seat - it's about building the foundation of your company. In this deep dive from Scaling The Unscalable, Engjell and Manuel share their unfiltered insights on attracting and selecting the right talent.

Learn why your hiring process really begins long before you post a job ad, how to balance attitude vs. skill, and the critical importance of authenticity in today's market. 

Discover practical tips on:
Building an attractive employer brand.
Crafting effective job descriptions.
Identifying key traits: curiosity, ownership, learnability.
Moving beyond "culture fit" to "culture add."
Asking interview questions that reveal genuine potential.
Understanding the 'work for yourself' mindset in candidates.

Stop guessing and start hiring strategically. Watch now for actionable advice from experienced entrepreneurs.

podcasts.title: Scaling the Unscalable #2 | A 20‑year entrepreneurial journey with Manuel Koelman
podcasts.description:
Ever wondered how to build a thriving business culture that is based on genuine connections and human-centric values? 🤔 
Join Engjell Rraklli in this episode of Scaling the Unscalable as he sits down with @PIRATEmanuel , the founder of Pirate Summit and PirateX! 🏴‍☠️ Manuel shares his 20-year entrepreneurial journey, revealing the secrets behind his unconventional yet highly successful approach to business.

In this conversation, you’ll learn:
- The story behind Pirate Summit and its unique "house rules" for authentic networking.
- How PirateX pivoted during the COVID crisis and thrived online.
- Manuel’s philosophy on leadership, flexible work culture, and empowering teams.
- Why putting humans first is the key to sustainable business success.
His perspective on the role of AI as a helpful "intern" in the future of work.


This episode is perfect for anyone looking to:
Scale their business while maintaining core values.
Cultivate a strong, engaged company culture.
Navigate challenges and embrace change effectively.
Understand the future of work and the role of AI.


Whether you're an entrepreneur, startup founder, or business leader, this episode is packed with valuable lessons on creating a positive, impactful, and scalable business.

podcasts.title: Scaling the unscalable #1 | Meet Kevin Riedl
podcasts.description:
Welcome to the very first episode of Scaling the Unscalable: Real Talk for Service-Based Business Builders. In this series, the host Engjell Rraklli sits down with founders, leaders, and builders to share the gritty, unfiltered realities of growing a service-based business.

In this episode, we talk with Kevin Riedl—CEO of Wavect and a trailblazer who’s navigated the ups and downs of scaling a company while serving niche clients in the Web 3 and Blockchain space. Together, we dive into overcoming setbacks, embracing messy growth, and learning lessons that can transform how you approach your own business.

Chapters:
0:00 – Intro & Welcome Kevin
1:00 – From Agency to Product Studio: Focus on Value
2:56 – Niche Evolution: Moving Beyond a Pure Web3 Focus
4:05 – The Problem with Focusing Solely on One Technology
7:10 – Biggest Business Challenge: Attracting the Right People & Leads
9:29 – Personal Challenge: Hiring for Character Over Competence
